Trust Fund Costs

) Purpose: This IRM provides policies and procedures for estimating costs providing services to the Old-Age, Survivors, Disability and Hospital and (OASDHI); Unemployment Compensation; and Black Lung Disability Trust Funds. (
) Audience: The audience for this IRM is business unit ﬁnance offices sible for estimating OASDHI, Unemployment Compensation, and Black Disability Trust Fund Costs. (
) Policy Owner: CFO owns these policies. (
) Program Owner: The CFO Cost Accounting and User Fees office oversees program. (
) Primary Stakeholders: Business units that estimate the trust fund costs are stakeholders for this IRM. (
) Program Goals: The program goals are to ensure internal controls for ing trust fund costs are implemented and cost estimates are accurate and consistent. (
) The IRS provides tax administration and support for the OASDHI, ment Compensation, and Black Lung trust fund programs. (

) The Black Lung Program. The Black Lung Beneﬁts Revenue Act of

tablished the Black Lung Disability Trust Fund within Treasury. It imposed excise tax on coal mine operators to fund monthly payments and medical beneﬁts to miners disabled by black lung disease. The Department of and Treasury share responsibility for administering the Black Lung Trust Fund. (

) Within Treasury, the Bureau of the Fiscal Service (Fiscal Service) is sible for administrating, maintaining and investing trust fund monies. The performs the following activities for FICA, FUTA and Black Lung taxes: a. Processing returns b. Processing payments c. Providing accounts management d. Collecting unpaid assessments e. Examining returns f. Assessing penalties and interest g. Performing document matching h. Providing appeal services i. Conducting criminal investigations (

) Treasury requires that the IRS report quarterly on the costs incurred for services for FICA, FUTA and Black Lung. The IRS provides Treasury a ten- year forecast of its costs to support the OASDHI, Unemployment Compensation, and Black Lung programs annually. (

) The Secretary of the Treasury (Secretary) pays the Treasury General Fund quarterly for IRS’s estimated costs of supporting the OASDHI and ment Compensation programs. ) The Associate CFO for Financial Management and Deputy Associate CFO Administrative Financial Management are responsible for: a. Ensuring policies, procedures, standards and controls for estimating fund costs are in place. b. Approving the Report on Quarterly Costs, the Annual and Ten-Year Funds Forecast Report and the Fiscal Year-End Trust Fund Report. (

) The Cost Accounting and User Fees office reports to the Deputy Associate CFO for Administrative Financial Management and is responsible for: a. Developing and communicating policies, procedures, standards and controls for estimating trust fund costs. b. Reviewing, validating and approving the business unit methodologies estimating trust fund costs. c. Calculating the corporate overhead rate to be applied to labor and costs (as described in IRM
, Calculating Cost Outside of Cost Module) to determine the full cost of supporting the trust funds. d. Reviewing Treasury Directive

, Administrative Expenses for Trust Funds, annually for updates. e. Developing quarterly costs templates for the business units. f. Preparing the Report on Quarterly Trust Fund Costs and the Annual Ten-Year Trust Funds Forecast Report based on business unit submis- sions. g. Preparing the Cost Analysis Variance Report, obtaining and validating justiﬁcations for material variances and any judgmentally sampled and adjusting the quarterly trust fund report as appropriate. h. Creating the Quarterly Estimate of Trust Fund Expenses billing document. i. Brieﬁng the Deputy Associate CFO for Administrative Financial Manage- ment on the Report on Quarterly Trust Fund Costs, the Annual and Ten- Year Trust Funds Forecast Report and the Fiscal Year-End Trust Fund Report. j. Submitting the approved Quarterly Estimate of Trust Fund Expenses to Fiscal Service. k. Reviewing the business units’ supporting documents and calculations on revolving schedule, brieﬁng management on the review results and providing feedback to the business units. l. Maintaining a detailed audit ﬁle with original source documents received from the business units, calculations used to compile reports and CFO executive approvals for a minimum of three years. (

The Cost Accounting and User Fees office reports to the Deputy Associate CFO for Administrative Financial Management and is responsible for:
Completing Quarterly Cost Templates within 25 days of the end of each quarter that include the labor and beneﬁt costs, applied overhead

and any other direct costs (e.g., travel, training, supplies, etc.) for processing returns, enforcing taxpayer compliance and providing customer service for the trust funds. c. Providing the Cost Accounting and User Fees office with explanations variances based on the stated materiality criteria in the Cost Analysis Variance Report and any additional variance the office judgmentally selects during the review process. d. Reviewing supporting documentation to ensure trust fund costs are rately estimated. e. Maintaining a detailed audit ﬁle with the original source documents electronic ﬁles used to prepare the Quarterly Cost Templates for a minimum of three years. f. Providing information to the Cost Accounting and User Fees office annually for preparing the Annual and Ten-Year Trust Funds Forecast Report for the next ﬁscal year and subsequent ten budget years. (
) The following program reports are used to review estimated trust fund quarterly. a. Report on Trust Fund Costs b. Cost Analysis Variance Report c. Quarterly Estimate of Trust Fund Expenses (
) Program effectiveness is measured by providing accurate and consistent estimated costs. (
) The following controls are in place to ensure compliance. a. Quarterly statement of difference b. Annual reviews of costing methodology (

) The following terms and deﬁnitions apply to this program. a. Beneﬁt rate - The rate calculated by dividing the total beneﬁt costs the organization by the total salary costs (permanent and temporary salaries) of the organization. Each program applies this rate to salary costs to determine the program’s beneﬁt costs. b. Corporate overhead rate - The rate calculated annually by the Cost counting and User Fees office and applied to total labor and beneﬁt to determine the full cost of providing services. c. Direct hours - Labor hours incurred by IRS employees that can be ciﬁcally identiﬁed with or assigned to a program, activity or output. d. Direct staff years - Direct hours converted to staff years using the year’s compensable hours. e. Federal Insurance Contributions Act - A U.S. payroll or tax imposed on both employees and employers to fund Social and Medicare. f. Full cost - All costs used in generating outputs, including all direct indirect costs. g. Full time equivalent - The total number of regular hours worked and approved leave taken by employees, divided by the ﬁscal year’s com- pensable hours. h. Federal Unemployment Tax Act - A U.S. payroll or employment tax imposed on employers to fund unemployment compensation. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) The business units use their respective timekeeping systems, subject matter experts and the Integrated Finance System (IFS) to estimate labor and costs supporting the trust funds. Costs include administrative and support of trust fund activities. (
) The Cost Accounting and User Fees office applies the corporate overhead to the business units’ costs to determine the full cost of supporting the trust funds. (

) Three trust fund reports are created quarterly by the Cost Accounting and Fees office and briefed to Financial Management leadership: a. Report on Trust Fund Costs b. Cost Analysis Variance Report c. Quarterly Estimate of Trust Fund Expenses (
) The Deputy Associate CFO for Financial Management approves the reports. (
) The Report on Trust Fund Costs consolidates the business unit costs for executive review and approval. (

) The Cost Accounting and User Fees Office: a. Develops and distributes the Quarterly Cost Template to business units. b. Calculates the overhead rate and reviews the methodology for trust fund costs annually. Internal Revenue Manual

) Business unit ﬁnance offices: a. Maintain desk procedures for developing quarterly trust fund cost estimates based on all direct costs, to include labor and beneﬁts and their related applied overhead as well as any other direct costs (e.g., travel, training, supplies, etc.), and coordinate changes with the Cost counting and User Fees office. b. Prepare, review and submit Quarterly Cost Template and justiﬁcations signiﬁcant variances in the Cost Analysis Variance Report to the Cost Accounting and User Fees office. c. Develop estimates to support the trust fund costs and complete the Quarterly Cost Template by:
Determining direct hours used to perform trust fund work.
Increasing direct hours to full time equivalent by including the rate of indirect hours.
Applying salary and beneﬁt rates to those hours to determine the total labor and beneﬁt costs for supporting the trust funds.
Applying the overhead rate to the total labor and beneﬁt costs.
Including any other identiﬁed direct costs (e.g., travel, training, supplies, etc.). (
